title: 106_s1898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Interstate Transportation of Dangerous Criminals Act of 2000" or "Jeanna's Act." Congress finds that States are increasingly using private prisoner transport companies for violent prisoners, leading to escapes and the need for oversight by the Attorney General. While most prefer law enforcement officers, fiscal or logistical concerns may necessitate the use of specialized private companies. Private prisoner transport companies are being used by states for violent prisoners, leading to escapes and prompting oversight by the Attorney General. While most prefer law enforcement officers, fiscal or logistical concerns may require the use of specialized private companies. If a government entity chooses to use a private prisoner transport company for violent prisoners, the company should be regulated to ensure public safety. In this Act, definitions are provided for "crime of violence," "private prisoner transport company," and "violent prisoner." The Act aligns the meanings of these terms with existing legal definitions in the United States Code. Federal regulation of prisoner transport companies. The Attorney General, in consultation with relevant organizations, will establish regulations for transporting violent prisoners across state lines. These regulations will cover background checks, drug testing, and training requirements for employees of prisoner transport companies. Employees transporting prisoners must undergo up to 100 hours of preservice training on restraints, searches, use of force, CPR, map reading, and defensive driving. There are restrictions on duty hours and minimum standards for personnel supervising violent prisoners. Transport entities must have 1 agent for every 6 prisoners. Minimum standards for employee uniforms and identification include wearing a uniform with a badge identifying the employee as a transportation officer. Standards also establish categories of violent prisoners required to wear brightly colored clothing for identification. Requirements for restraints during transportation include leg shackles and double-locked handcuffs. Private prisoner transport companies must notify local law enforcement 24 hours in advance of scheduled stops. The regulations for private prisoner transport companies include notifying law enforcement immediately in case of a violent prisoner escape and setting minimum safety standards for violent prisoners. Federal standards for these companies should not be stricter than those for federal agencies like the US Marshals Service. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. Violators of the regulations established by this Act may face a civil penalty up to $10,000 per violation, restitution to entities for costs related to apprehending escaped violent prisoners, as a result of non-compliance with regulations.
